channel.title: Course Overview on Data Science for Biotechnology
channel.description: Recent content in Course Overview on Data Science for Biotechnology

item.title: Cool Companies
item.description: Cool & Relevant Companies NOTE: we are not sponsoring these companies in any way, shape, or form. This is just to help and hopefully inspire people to dip their toe into the field. Illumina Benevolent AI Novo Nordisk Corti AI Reverie Labs Buoy Health Siligon Therapeutics

item.title: Datasets
item.description: Datasets Healthcare / Medicine / Biotech Realm Pfizer Vaccine Tweets COVID-19 Open Research Dataset Challenge (CORD-19) Novel Corona Virus 2019 Dataset Heart Disease UCI Chest X-Ray Images (Pneumonia) NeurIPS 2020: Data Science for COVID-19 (DS4C) Miscellaneous Datasets that you can load with Python 5 real world datasets for honing your EDA skills 1.88 million US Wildfires Spotify Dataset 1921-2020, 160k+ Tracks 120 years of Olympic History: Athletes and Results Interesting Data to Visualize Plotly Datasets (CSV)

item.title: Week 1
item.description: Week 1: Introduction to the Course Required: Create a Github account and email us your username (we will add you to our DS4B organization on GitHub) Once you are added to the GitHub DS4B organization, create a new repository (within the organization) for your DS4B coursework. Name it <first name>-<last name>. Click the “Add a README file” button when initializing the repo. Make the repository private. Clone the repository on your local machine.

item.title: Week 1
item.description: Week 1: Introduction to the Course Links Class Slides Data Science vs. Computer Science Jamboard Biotechnology Jamboard Jupyter Notebook Setup Creating a GitHub Repository Kaggle Datasets Creating a Simple Linear Regression using sklearn Jupyter Notebook Installation OPTION 1: Anaconda > Jupyter Notebooks $ conda install -c conda-forge notebook OPTION 2: If you already have Python installed, you can use a software management tool called pip. $ pip3 install jupyter OR

item.title: Week 2
item.description: Week 2: Exploratory Data Analysis Required: Download Tableau Desktop software for next week Get student activation key here Do some EDA on a dataset of your choice (from sklearn or Kaggle OR check out https://datascience4biotech.com/resources/datasets/) Add it to Github so we can see! Come up with an initial research question which motivates your exploration of the data. Write 2-3 sentences in your README.md about an interesting fact or correlation you discovered.

item.title: Week 2
item.description: Week 2: Exploratory Data Analysis Links Class Slides Life Expectancy Dataset Kaggle Datasets Introduction to Pandas Dataframes Google Colab Demo EDA Checklist What question(s) are you trying to solve (or prove right / wrong)? What kind of data do you have and how do you treat different types? What’s missing from the data and how do you deal with it? Where are the outliers adn why should you care about them?

item.title: Week 3
item.description: Week 3: Data Visualization Required: Find 1 good and 1 bad data visualization, link them on your Github README! Briefly explain what makes the good visualization good or bad. Think about intuitiveness, data-ink ratio, color scheme, retinal variables, labeling, interactiveness, etc.. NOTE: links in your README can be created like so [name or description of the visualization](paste url here) Finish your Tableau visualization. Take a screenshot of it and upload it to GitHub (if you want to get fancy, you can embed the image in your README).
